susanegross: I know this will be one of a zillion comments, likely to get lost in the sheer volume. I don’t know why you would even SUGGEST anyone might “feel sorry” for you for being raw and honest. There is far, far, FAR too little of that around. Too many people are putting their filtered lives and filtered images up here — frankly, I can’t take that bullshit. I feel scared and rageful and mournful SO MUCH OF THE TIME. But so many people don’t want to feel that kind of rawness. But, it’s all I got these days. It really is. It would be so much better for ALL of us if people seriously got real about where they are. Seeing all the fakery all around makes it all so much worse. There is true connection in honesty. And that’s really all we have at the end of the day — being able to connect, to be honest about the real shit, to love each other.

kathleenbush: Hey lady, be gentle with yourself 💛 one day at a time. Incremental progress, big or small, especially with writing a book, is most important, not solving it all in one day. Let go of the little things that add to the stress and pick them back up when you’re ready! You got this!
ashleyll0132: It’s unsettling, right? The language of man’s heart not so satisfyingly mapped out like the physical sciences; there’s definitely a greater intricacy that continually challenges us when we think we’ve got it all together. You’re definitely not alone in this and your words, whatever the context/state, continue to be a rich resource. So thanks for your energy in pressing on. All of the greatest minds in recorded history have yet to provide an end this “hole” in our hearts. But your persistence, I believe, reveals you know your tears are not falling unseen. Each is a reminder that love’s not a cold, rigid equation to be solved. It’s wild, steep, costly to pursue...everything we’d attribute to something being precious and what we cannot help but crave. The “solution” is dynamic, we’re never meant to exhaust it’s resource/revelation, and in that hopefully there’s some peace knowing your efforts to understand and share your ever-expanding hues of knowledge and love worthwhile and very much needed by so many others trying to find their way.

albregia: Never think that your mental health takes away from positive things. Even when you’re experiencing personal growth and success, it is normal to struggle. It is change, it is pressure, it is something you haven’t lived through yet, and you don’t stop being strong and brave and thankful if you feel like crying and walking around with a blanket covering you. No one asks to feel this way. It’s a symptom of a larger disease, and just because you dared to be the brilliant lovely woman you are doesn’t mean you have to quietly suffer through anxiety and depression. I see you, Jen. I admire you a whole fucking lot. And you absolutely need to cut yourself some slack. You can be blessed and struggle. You can feel privileged and lost. But you don’t deserve the heartache and the guilt.
